caption: #: -- - ; , CNB recently mounted a successful operation following investigations on persons who bought drugs via a chat application, arresting 5 suspects and seizing drugs worth about $71,000 and some cash.Forced entry had to be effected at both locations during the op as the occupants refused entry to CNB officers. Subsequent searches of the residential units and suspects cars uncovered various types of drugs, a digital weighing scale, drug paraphernalia and cash amounting to $3,600. Several scheduled weapons were also uncovered and seized.DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:Through our investigations on persons who had bought drugs via a chat application, CNB successfully mounted the operations on 27 September and arrested five persons for their suspected involvement in drug trafficking. Drug offenders who think that such chat applications would enable them to transact anonymously cannot be more wrong. There is no safe haven, whether online or offline, for such nefarious activities. CNB will continue to monitor, track down and take decisive actions against them.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: CNB recently mounted a successful operation following investigations on persons who bought drugs via a chat application, arresting 5 suspects and seizing drugs worth about $71,000 and some cash. Forced entry had to be effected at both locations during the operation as the occupants refused entry to CNB officers. Subsequent searches of the residential units and suspects' cars uncovered various types of drugs, a digital weighing scale, drug paraphernalia, and cash amounting to $3,600. Several scheduled weapons were also uncovered and seized. DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations: "Through our investigations on persons who had bought drugs via a chat application, CNB successfully mounted the operations on 27 September and arrested five persons for their suspected involvement in drug trafficking. Drug offenders who think that such chat applications would enable them to transact anonymously cannot be more wrong. There is no safe haven, whether online or offline, for such nefarious activities. CNB will continue to monitor, track down and take decisive actions against them." Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 15-- 58 - - 58 suspected drug offenders were arrested in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 11 to 15 September 2023. The youngest arrested in this island-wide operation was a 15-year-old local student. In total, about 708g of heroin, 670g of Ice, 63g of cannabis, amongst other drugs, as well as cash amounting to $13,390 were seized. The drugs have an estimated street value of about $294,000. In the morning of 11 September, acting on information received, CNB officers arrested a 52-year-old Singaporean man in the vicinity of Marsiling Road for suspected drug trafficking offences. The man was escorted to his residential unit where a search was conducted. Ice and ketamine, and various drug paraphernalia were amongst the drugs recovered from his residential unit and from the mans bag. About 505g of heroin and 13g of Ice were seized from another residential unit in the vicinity of Marsiling Road in the afternoon of 12 September. A 47-year-old Singaporean man and a 36-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested for suspected drug offences. Forced entry was effected as the occupants refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. Arising from investigations following the anti-drug operations at a Joo Chiat nightspot on 7 September , CNB officers arrested a 28-year-old Singaporean man and a 31-year-old foreign woman for suspected drug offences in the evening of 12 September. The man was arrested in a hotel in the vicinity of Race Course Road where about 15g of ketamine, Ecstasy tablets weighing about 14g, and cash amounting to $9,300 were seized from his hotel room. Later the same evening, CNB officers arrested the woman in the vicinity of Petain Road. CNB officers then escorted both suspects to the mans hideout in the vicinity of Petain Road where more drugs were found. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: : , , CNBOnTheMove: From 7 to 10 September 2023, a series of enforcement operations was conducted at nightspots located in the areas of Joo Chiat, Marina Bay and Bugis. Three male Singaporeans and one female foreign national were arrested for suspected drug-related offences, the youngest being a 19-year-old Singaporean teenager. A total of about 3g of Ice, 98g of ketamine, 46g of Ecstasy tablets and 60g of powdery substance believed to be controlled drugs were seized.The enforcement operation involved officers from CNB and as part of sustained efforts to clamp down on illegal activities, including drug offences and crime.Close to 20 persons were checked during the enforcement operations at the nightspot on 7 September. At around the same time, a 29-year-old female foreign national, who was observed by CNB officers to have earlier exited the nightspot, was arrested in a nearby open-air carpark. About 1g of ketamine was recovered from her. In follow-up operations the same night, CNB officers arrested a 26-year-old man in the vicinity of Dunman Road. About 3g of Ice, 46g of Ecstasy tablets, 90g of Ketamine and 60g of powdery substance believed to contain controlled drugs were seized from the vehicle he was in. CNB officers also arrested a 53-year-old Singaporean man in the vicinity of Petain Road, and about 7g of ketamine were recovered from him.During an overnight enforcement operation conducted from 9 to 10 September in four nightlife establishments located near Marina Bay and Bugis, a 19-year-old male Singaporean was arrested for suspected drug-related offences, among over 90 persons checked in the establishments.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.OneHomeTeamFull story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: . , . ; - - A 15-year-old girl and a 17-year-old boy were amongst the 130 arrested. In total, about 1.3kg of heroin, 2.5kg of cannabis and 486g of Ice amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were found in the island-wide anti-drug operation from 14 25 August. Cash amounting to $1,503.05 was also seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $453,800. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Kallang, Marine Parade, Pasir Ris and Woodlands.In the afternoon of 14 August, two teenagers aged 15 and 17 and six others aged between 37 and 59, were arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Woodlands Street 81. Forced entry was effected as the occupants had disregarded the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. The two teenagers climbed onto the ledge from the bedroom window of the unit on the second floor in a bid to evade arrest. CNB officers were able to persuade them to return to safety. The other suspects put up a violent struggle during the arrest and had to be subdued by officers. Drugs and various drug paraphernalia were found within the unit and from the ground beneath the unit. In another operation, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Ghim Moh Road in the evening of 23 August, and arrested a 24-year-old Singaporean man and a 19-year-old Singaporean woman. About 2.4kg cannabis, 269g of Ice amongst other drugs and vape devices containing drugs were found. A 29-year-old Singaporean man was later arrested in the same vicinity for suspected drug offences. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: $, ; On 26 July 2023, CNB officers mounted an operation in Yishun and parts of Jurong. A total of six Singaporeans aged between the ages of 17 and 28 were arrested for drug offences. The drugs seized included almost 1kg of 'Ice', about 7.8kg of cannabis, 1,218 Erimin-5 tablets as well as various quantities of ketamine, 'Ecstasy' tablets and LSD stamps.The 'Ice' seized would have fed the addiction of about 560 abusers while the cannabis would have fed about 1,110 abusers, for a week.DAC Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the island-wide operation:Yesterdays anti-drug blitz to disrupt the operations of drug syndicates saw large seizures of drugs and the arrests of young drug offenders. Syndicates are heartless and have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences that carry severe consequences. CNB will continue to keep up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers who profit off the misery of drug abusers and their loved ones. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing and we intend to keep the hunt on for those connected with these cases.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

The drugs seized included almost 1kg of 'Ice', about 7.8kg of cannabis, 1,218 Erimin-5 tablets as well as various quantities of ketamine, 'Ecstasy' tablets and LSD stamps. The 'Ice' seized would have fed the addiction of about 560 abusers while the cannabis would have fed about 1,110 abusers, for a week. DAC, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the island-wide operation: "Yesterday's anti-drug blitz to disrupt the operations of drug syndicates saw large seizures of drugs and the arrests of young drug offenders. Syndicates are heartless and have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences that carry severe consequences. CNB will continue to keep up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers who profit off the misery of drug abusers and their loved ones. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing and we intend to keep the hunt on for those connected with these cases." Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: $ On 5 July 2023 at about 6.40pm, the Police responded to a call for assistance at a residential unit along Jalan Binchang. There, a 28-year-old Singaporean man put up a violent struggle to resist arrest and necessary force was used to subdue him. A police officer sustained minor injuries during the arrest. In the unit, the Police found approximately 450g of Ice and 2.2kg of cannabis, amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia. CNB officers were subsequently called to the scene and the case was referred to CNB for further investigations. The total amount of drugs seized have an estimated street value of $173,000, and the Ice and cannabis seized can feed the addiction of about 580 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Police investigations are also ongoing for the offence of voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from the discharge of his duty under Section 332 of the Penal Code 1871. The Home Team has zero tolerance towards such acts of violence towards public servants who are carrying out their duties, and will not hesitate to take firm action against those who endanger the safety of our officers.CNBOnTheMove OneHomeTeamFull story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: 145 - Ten youths aged between 16 and 24 were amongst the 145 suspected drug offenders arrested in CNBs island-wide drug operation from 5 to 19 May. About 1.7kg of heroin, 1.4kg of Ice, 348g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized in total. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $354,000.On 8 May, six youths, aged between 17 and 21, were arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok South Avenue 2 for suspected drug abuse. Another four youths were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in a hotel in the vicinity of North Bridge Road on 11 May. Superintendent Christopher Lee, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement A and E Divisions, said of the island-wide operation: During this series of anti-drug operations, CNB arrested groups of youths who are suspected to have abused drugs in a friends home or in a hotel room. The 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey conducted by the Institute of Mental Health has found that residences - ones own home or a friends home - were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption. The survey has also found that for those who abused drugs, the mean age of onset of drug abuse was 15.9 and 52% of these abusers started out with cannabis. It is crucial for parents and family members to be vigilant to warning signs of drug abuse and help their child seek help early. We strongly encourage parents to have conversations about the harms of drugs with their child early to build up their resilience against drugs and to help our young ones thrive and flourish in a safe and healthy environment.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: , $ ; CNB officers recently neutralised drug activities during operations conducted in the vicinities of Jalan Bukit Merah and Tampines Street 22. During the operations forced entry had to be effected into one of the residential units, while a suspect attempted to evade officers by scaling down the kitchen window into a neighbouring unit. The suspect was subsequently arrested.Drugs including heroin, Ice, as well as cash amounting to $36,550, knives, contraband cigarettes and drug paraphernalia were seized from the targeted residential units, suspects vehicles and even locations like the dry-riser outside one of the units.The heroin and Ice seized would have fed the addiction of about 1550 abusers for a week.SUPT William Tan, Senior Assistant Director of Intelligence Operations, said of the operations:Drug trafficking and abuse pose serious threats to our society. The recent two operations involving large seizures of controlled drugs, dangerous weapons and cash are timely reminders that we must never let our guard down in our fight against drugs. Our officers will continue to remain steadfast in our mission to tackle drug offenders and neutralise drug activities.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: CNB officers recently neutralised drug activities during operations conducted in the vicinities of Jalan Bukit Merah and Tampines Street 22. During the operations, forced entry had to be effected into one of the residential units, while a suspect attempted to evade officers by scaling down the kitchen window into a neighbouring unit. The suspect was subsequently arrested. Drugs including heroin, Ice, as well as cash amounting to $36,550, knives, contraband cigarettes and drug paraphernalia were seized from the targeted residential units, suspects' vehicles and even locations like the dry-riser outside one of the units. The heroin and Ice seized would have fed the addiction of about 1550 abusers for a week. Senior Assistant Director of Intelligence Operations said of the operations: "Drug trafficking and abuse pose serious threats to our society. The recent two operations involving large seizures of controlled drugs, dangerous weapons and cash are timely reminders that we must never let our guard down in our fight against drugs. Our officers will continue to remain steadfast in our mission to tackle drug offenders and neutralise drug activities."

caption: #: . ; CNB conducted a series of island-wide operations from 11 to 19 April 2023, targeting drug transactions conducted through encrypted chat applications. The more than 11kg of total drugs seized (including 9.5kg of cannabis) had an estimated street value of S$560,000. The areas covered included a residential block near Haig Road, where a 42-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking at the void deck on 11 April. About 783g of cannabis, 17g of Ice, 97g of Ecstasy, 60 Erimin-5 tablets and 13 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized from him. Officers later recovered about 8.5kg of cannabis, 766g of Ice, 461g of Ecstasy, 320g of ketamine, 390 Erimin-5 tablets, 56 LSD stamps, 122g of substances believed to be controlled drugs, and various drug paraphernalia from his residential unit.During an operation conducted on 18 April, a 24-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested in a residential unit near Compassvale Link, where about 2.3g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized.On 19 April, 2.8g of cannabis was also seized from a residential unit near Choa Chu Kang Crescent, where an 18-year-old male student was arrested. SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:The use of chat applications that allow for encrypted communication, such as Telegram, has become increasingly popular among drug offenders to buy and sell illicit drugs. Many of these drug offenders think that such chat applications would enable them to transact anonymously. They cannot be more wrong.CNB has observed this phenomenon as early as 2019 and has since arrested more than 500 drug offenders who partake in illegal online drug transactions. Our officers will continue to monitor emerging trends and evasive tactics, and launch well-timed operations to take down drug offenders.Full story at linkinbio

caption: #: ~. - 161 suspected drug offenders were arrested by CNB officers in an island-wide drug operation from 10 to 14 April 2023. About 2,876g of heroin, 209g of Ice, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $234,000. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Ang Mo Kio, Hougang, Geylang and Toa Payoh.A 59-year-old man was arrested from his hideout in the vicinity of Lorong 7 Toa Payoh on 11 April. Forced entry was effected as the man had refused to heed the lawful orders of CNB officers to open the door. CNB officers recovered about 489g of heroin from the man and seized about 2,067g of heroin, 140g of Ice, 1 bottle of methadone, and various drug paraphernalia from the hideout.Two Singaporean men, were also arrested on 10 April, for suspected drug offences in a hotel room in the vicinity of Geylang Road. About 226g of heroin amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized. Superintendent Qamarul Zaman Bin Hussin, Deputy Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement L Division, said of the island-wide operation: Drug abuse is a serious threat to our society and if left unchecked, can bring about dire consequences to the safety and well-being of our people. Our officers will not let up our enforcement efforts against drug traffickers and abusers, so that our families and children can live in a safe and drug-free environment.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: : ; On 31 March, CNB officers arrested a 39-year-old man for suspected drug abuse from within a residential unit at Ang Mo Kio Ave 3. 1g of Ice and drug paraphernalia were recovered from the toilet bowl. In a follow-up operation that same night, officers intercepted a 29-year-old man in a vehicle in the vicinity of Selegie Road. Ecstasy and other drugs were seized. Separately, a 25-year-old man was also arrested for suspected drug trafficking in a nightspot in the vicinity of Prinsep Street, while five other men aged between 26 and 28 were also arrested there on suspicion of drug abuse.During the operation, a total of about 65g of Ice, 83g of ketamine, a packet of Ecstasy tablets weighing about 110g and 24 Ecstasy tablets and 32g of substances believed to be controlled drugs with an estimated street value of $37,000 were seized.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said The operation is aimed at preventing drugs from proliferating on our streets and nightspots. As activity resumes after the pandemic, the Central Narcotics Bureau has also resumed our anti-drug operations at nightspots Our advice is clear stay away from drugs.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Separately, a 25-year-old man was also arrested for suspected drug trafficking in a nightspot in the vicinity of Prinsep Street, while five other men aged between 26 and 28 were also arrested there on suspicion of drug abuse. During the operation, a total of about 65g of Ice, 83g of ketamine, a packet of Ecstasy tablets weighing about 110g and 24 Ecstasy tablets and 32g of substances believed to be controlled drugs with an estimated street value of $37,000 were seized. SUpt Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said the operation is aimed at preventing drugs from proliferating on our streets and nightspots. As activity resumes after the pandemic, the Central Narcotics Bureau has also resumed our anti-drug operations at nightspots. Our advice is clear: stay away from drugs.

caption: #: , , . - Following up on information on a suspected drug trafficker, CNB officers were deployed to the vicinity of Ubi Ave 1 on 13 March 2023. Officers raided a unit and arrested a 32-year-old man and a 22-year-old woman. About 345g of Ice, 778g of cannabis, 235g of ketamine, 41 Ecstasy tablets, 100 Erimin-5 tablets, 50 LSD stamps, and various drug paraphernalia were recovered. A large number of weapons including an airsoft pistol, machetes, swords, and knuckle dusters were also seized.During the course of the operation, another 32-year-old man was arrested near Bukit Timah. 5g of Ice and drug paraphernalia were recovered from him.The total seizure of 350g of Ice and 778g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 310 abusers for a week.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operation:The operation on 13 March is an example of the dangers that our officers face every day. Drug traffickers may be armed, increasing the risk to our officers. But this will not deter us. CNB officers will remain steadfast in our efforts to prevent drugs from flowing to the streets.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing, and the Police are investigating the 32-year-old man arrested near Ubi Ave 1 for possession of offensive weapons.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing, and the Police are investigating the 32-year-old man arrested near Ubi Ave 1 for possession of offensive weapons.

caption: #: ; In the early hours of 8 March, Police attended to a traffic accident involving a car and a truck in the vicinity of Yishun Ave 7. The 34-year-old male driver of the car fled the scene and about 55g of cannabis, amongst other drugs together with various drug paraphernalia, and an offensive weapon were recovered from the vehicle and in a bag dropped by the man at a nearby residential block. In a follow-up operation conducted by Police and CNB officers in the same evening, officers arrested a 34-year-old woman in the vicinity of Macpherson who led officers to the man hiding in a nearby residential unit. From within the unit, about 10g of heroin, 7g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized. Upon further checks, CNB officers located a parcel suspected to have been left for the man on another floor in the same residential block, and various drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the parcel.The arrests were part of an island-wide drug operation from 6-10 March 2023 where CNB arrested 77 suspected drug offenders. During the operation, controlled drugs of about 45g of heroin, 250g of Ice, 250g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $49,000.Superintendent Mohaideen Abdul Kadir, Deputy Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement J Division, said of the island-wide operation: We must remember that drugs cause harm and suffering not only to those who abuse them, but also to their families. CNB will continue to keep up the momentum of our enforcement efforts to combat the scourge of drugs, and launch timely enforcement operations to neutralise drug activities. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: , Station Inspector Marlina Djumadi, who was at the scene where a 2-month old child was found together with her mother, who was suspected of abusing drugs during and after her pregnancy.An island-wide operation conducted from 6 to 17 February 2023 found 133 suspected drug offenders arrested and on 9 February, a 2-month old infant was found with a 32-year-old woman, a suspected drug abuser. The operation was conducted at a residential unit in the vicinity of Sembawang Drive. A small amount of heroin, Ice and various drug paraphernalia was seized from the unit. The woman, who was under investigation for drugs offences since last year, is suspected to have had abused drugs during and after her pregnancy. Appropriate arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the infant was taken care of, and the infant was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.Station Inspector Marlina Djumadi, a CNB officer who was involved in the operation, said:As a parent myself, we will always do things in the best interests of our children. I was saddened to learn that the woman may have continued to abuse drugs during her pregnancy, possibly endangering the health of her newborn child. Drug abuse is not a victimless crime it has dire consequences on families and innocent children. I hope that the woman will be able to get the help that she needs, so that she will be able to better care, protect and provide for her child.About 64g of heroin, 528g of Ice, 94g of cannabis, 512g of ketamine amongst other drugs with an estimated street value of about $231,600 were seized from the island-wide operation. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbioDrugFreeSG

caption: : - ; CNBOnTheMoveEnough heroin to feed the addiction of about 3,200 abusers for a week was seized in a recent operation conducted by CNB officers. The 6,781g of heroin, which were recovered in several bundles, packets and straws on the 49-year-old suspect, at his residence, at his suspected hideout, as well as thrown out of the windows, were seized along with an assortment of other controlled substances including Ice, cannabis and Erimin-5 tablets.A woman and two other men were also arrested during the operation.Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

A woman and two other men were also arrested during the operation. Investigations into the suspects' drug activities are ongoing. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.

caption: #: , ' -- , - ; , During an island-wide operation from 9 to 13 January 2023, CNB officers arrested a total of 88 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of more than $56,000.In one of the cases, a 47-year-old woman, her 48-year-old husband and her 18-year-old son, along with two other Singaporeans, were arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Bukit Merah. Heroin, cannabis, Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from their home. Preliminary investigations also found that all five persons urine tested positive for controlled drugs.In another case, a 52-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Sultan. An assortment of controlled drugs, including 224g of tampered drink sachets believed to contain methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), were seized from his residential unit and from his vehicle parked nearby. Superintendent Lee Pin How, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement F and L Division, said of the island-wide operation: Drugs have a devastating impact on individuals, families and communities abusers are robbed of the opportunity to live their lives to the fullest, relationships are destroyed, and the larger community pays a hefty price in dealing with the wide-ranging consequences that drug abuse can bring. CNB will continue to persevere in safeguarding a safe and drug-free society for our people and our children.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Fully story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Superintendent, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement F and L Division, said of the island-wide operation: Drugs have a devastating impact on individuals, families, and communities; abusers are robbed of the opportunity to live their lives to the fullest, relationships are destroyed, and the larger community pays a hefty price in dealing with the wide-ranging consequences that drug abuse can bring. CNB will continue to persevere in safeguarding a safe and drug-free society for our people and our children. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: Two brothers, one aged 17 and the other 25, were arrested by CNB officers on 10 Jan 2023. About 1kg of cannabis, 198 LSD stamps, 538 Erimin-5 tablets and other drugs with a total estimated street value of $124,000 were seized.Preliminary investigations revealed that the controlled drugs seized may be linked to drug transactions conducted on Telegram. CNB is aware that some drug offenders and syndicates have been leveraging on encrypted messaging applications like Telegram to conduct their drug activities. These drug offenders may think that such applications can offer them a certain level of anonymity to carry out their illegal activities, and evade CNBs surveillance. CNB is monitoring such developments closely, and has been taking regular enforcement actions against drug offenders who use the Telegram platform for their activities. Regardless of the platform or tactics used in an attempt to evade detection, there is no safe haven for drug offenders in Singapore. Investigations into the drug activities are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSG

caption: #: : 8 , 6 6 Singaporeans were arrested by CNB officers for suspected drug trafficking offences on 29 and 30 November 2022. More than 8kg of cannabis, 415g of heroin and other substances with an estimated street value of $304,000, were seized during the operation. The seizure of 8,194g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 1,160 cannabis abusers for a week, while the seizure of 415g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 200 heroin abusers for a week. In the evening of 29 November, CNB officers arrested a 24-year-old man and a 25-year-old woman, where about 4.9kg of cannabis was found in their vehicle. That same evening, the man and woman were escorted to their hideout in a condominium at Upper Paya Lebar Road, where a 46-year-old man and a 32-year-old woman were arrested. A 54-year-old man who returned to the hideout later that evening was also arrested. About 3.3kg of cannabis, 382g of heroin and other drugs were found. Another suspect, a 41-year-old man, was subsequently arrested at the ground floor of the same condominium block. CNB officers later escorted him to his residence located in the vicinity of Anchorvale Road, where controlled drugs were also found. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, anyone found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: : New psychoactive substances (NPS) can contain newly synthesised chemicals designed to mimic the psychoactive effects of existing controlled drugs, and are the second-most commonly abused drugs in Singapore. Earlier last month, CNB added 13 new psychoactive substances (NPS) to the Misuse of Drug Act (MDA) as Class A controlled drugs. Here are 5 key takeaways about NPS use in Asia: Statistics on Ketamine:1. Amongst the seizures of synthetic NPS in 2020, the largest quantities were of ketamine. 2. Most of these ketamine seizures were reported in the East Asian and SouthEast Asian regions: the top 3 countries are Malaysia, Thailand and China (in descending order). 3. Since 2015, the ketamine market has continued to expand in SouthEast Asia, notably Thailand. Statistics on other NPS:4. Other NPS are used and likely on the rise in SouthEast Asia: seizures of synthetic cannabinoids in Singapore have sharply increased over the last 5 years. 5. In 2020, NPS abusers constituted the 2nd largest group (9%) after methamphetamine abusers among new abusers arrested in Singapore. The number of NPS abusers decreased by 7% in 2021. Click here for the full report: WDR2022
cleaned_caption:
New psychoactive substances (NPS) can contain newly synthesised chemicals designed to mimic the psychoactive effects of existing controlled drugs, and are the second-most commonly abused drugs in Singapore. Earlier last month, CNB added 13 new psychoactive substances (NPS) to the Misuse of Drug Act (MDA) as Class A controlled drugs. Here are 5 key takeaways about NPS use in Asia: 

Statistics on Ketamine:
1. Amongst the seizures of synthetic NPS in 2020, the largest quantities were of ketamine. 
2. Most of these ketamine seizures were reported in the East Asian and SouthEast Asian regions: the top 3 countries are Malaysia, Thailand and China (in descending order). 
3. Since 2015, the ketamine market has continued to expand in SouthEast Asia, notably Thailand.

Statistics on other NPS:
4. Other NPS are used and likely on the rise in SouthEast Asia: seizures of synthetic cannabinoids in Singapore have sharply increased over the last 5 years. 
5. In 2020, NPS abusers constituted the 2nd largest group (9%) after methamphetamine abusers among new abusers arrested in Singapore. The number of NPS abusers decreased by 7% in 2021. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

caption: CNBOnTheMove: Three 14-year-olds and two 16-year-olds were arrested for suspected drug trafficking in recent operations. About 226g of cannabis, estimated to be worth close to $7,000, food products believed to be infused with cannabis, and drug utensils were seized. The teenagers are students from local and international schools.In one of the operations, CNB officers arrested a boy and a girl, both aged 16, for suspected drug trafficking offences in the vicinity of Bukit Batok Street 21 following ICA officers' detection of a parcel containing suspected drug paraphernalia. About 59g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized from the girls home.AC Lim Fung Suan, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 2, said: CNB stands firm in our belief that everyone in Singapore should have the right to live in an environment free from the scourge of drugs. We urge parents to partner us to keep our young ones safe. By talking to them about the harms of drugs, and paying attention to their friends and activities, we believe that preventive education is key and CNB will continue to work closely with our partners in schools and the community, so that everyone is made aware of the harms of drug abuse, and can help to spread the anti-drug message and caution their loved ones against getting involved in drugs.Members of the public can contact CNB at its hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they are worried that their children may be involved with drugs. Those who have drug-related information can also call our hotline or submit the information at story .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSG GuardiansofDrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam

The seizure of 2.28kg of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 330 abusers for a week. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: : ; 13 2 5 suspected drug offenders, aged between 31 and 42, were arrested in 2 operations conducted on 26 September 2022. A total of about 8kg of cannabis and 20g of what is believed to be cannabis seeds, 2kg of Ice and 2kg of heroin, amongst other drugs were seized. The drugs, with a street value of about $790,000, are sufficient to feed about 1,180 cannabis abusers, 1,240 Ice abusers and 960 heroin abusers for a week. In one operation in the vicinity of Rivervale Street, CNB officers arrested a Singaporean man. From his vehicle, CNB officers recovered a total of about 6kg of cannabis and other drugs. The discovery included 3 fire extinguishers which had been hollowed out, of which one was found to have contained about 4.5kg of the cannabis. From his residence, another 2kg of cannabis and 20g of what is believed to be cannabis seeds, amongst other drugs were seized. In another operation, CNB officers arrested 2 Singaporean men in the vicinity of Upper Serangoon View. Both men put up a violent struggle to resist arrest, and necessary force was used to subdue them. A total of about 2kg of heroin, 1kg of Ice, amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized from one of the mans residence in the same vicinity. A female foreign national who later returned to the unit was also arrested. From the second mans residence located in the vicinity of Yishun Ave 4, about 12g of heroin amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were also seized. A female foreign national who was in the unit was also arrested. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 8 A 42-year-old Singaporean man was arrested by CNB officers at Geylang Road for suspected drug offences on 6 September 2022. The man had put up a violent struggle to resist arrest and necessary force was used to subdue him. A total of about 134g of Ice, 1,671g of cannabis, among other controlled drugs were recovered from the 42-year-old man. The man was escorted to two more locations where more controlled drugs were found. In total, about 659g of Ice, 5,093g of cannabis, 442g of ketamine, 252g of Ecstasy tablets, 145 Erimin-5 tablets, 17 bottles of liquid believed to contain 1,195g GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) and 535g of tampered sachets of beverage mix believed to contain controlled drugs were seized during the operation. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $343,000. The seizure of 659g of Ice and 5,093g of cannabis is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 1,100 abusers for a week.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operation:CNB will continue to take decisive and firm action against drug syndicates and traffickers seeking to bring harm to our community and profit off the misery of abusers family and loved ones. Drugs have no place in our society, and my officers will stop at nothing to bring those involved in this case to justice.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: : In view of the legalisation of cannabis consumption for non-medical purposes in various countries, here are 4 key takeaways about the global demand and supply of cannabis, and cannabis-related crimes. In countries/states where the non-medical use of cannabis has been legalised:1. Perceptions of cannabis harms have decreased; the number of people with cannabis-use disorders (such as psychiatric disorders and suicides) increased. 2. Cannabis consumption among adolescents remains much higher, as compared to countries that have not legalised non-medical cannabis. 3. Cannabis products are becoming more dangerous than ever, as such products with higher potency levels have been found. Cannabis herbs seized in Europe and the US are found to contain increasing levels of THC content over the years. Statistics on Cannabis:4. Cannabis remains the most commonly used and widely produced drug worldwide. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

caption: #: ; . ( , ) On 17 Aug 2022, CNB conducted two anti-drug operations. During the first, at a residential unit in the vicinity of Boon Lay Drive, two men put up a violent struggle and were subdued with necessary force. A woman who was hiding behind a rack was also promptly arrested. Over 2.5kg of heroin, which was suspected to have been thrown into the rubbish chute prior to the arrests, was also recovered. Another 1.1kg of heroin was also seized during a second operation in the vicinity of Fernvale Street.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: On 17 Aug 2022, CNB conducted two anti-drug operations. During the first, at a residential unit in the vicinity of Boon Lay Drive, two men put up a violent struggle and were subdued with necessary force. A woman who was hiding behind a rack was also promptly arrested. Over 2.5kg of heroin, which was suspected to have been thrown into the rubbish chute prior to the arrests, was also recovered. Another 1.1kg of heroin was also seized during a second operation in the vicinity of Fernvale Street. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.

caption: : CNBs annual statistics release 2021 show methamphetamine (meth) to be the most commonly abused drug in Singapore: 58% of drug abusers arrested in 2021 were meth abusers. Meth abusers also made up the largest proportion of NEW abusers arrested in 2021 at 76%. Taking a look at the global drug situation, here are 2 key takeaways about meth use. 1. Methamphetamine remains the most used amphetamine-type stimulant (ATS) in the SouthEast Asian region, with almost 200 000 people being treated for meth abuse. 2. Meth seizures in SouthEast Asia saw a 30% increase from 2019 to 2020. Myanmar reported the highest increase, followed by Malaysia. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

caption: #: ; . , . . During a recent island-wide operation, officers arrested a total of 100 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of $470,000. The areas covered included Sumang Walk, where heroin, Ice and other drugs as well as cash amounting to about $4,327 was seized from a 56-year-old Singaporean man suspected of drug trafficking. More than 9kg of cannabis, other drugs, as well as large quantities of cash, including some in foreign currencies, were also seized in the vicinity of Haig Road and in Geylang, where several foreign nationals were arrested.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: - ; In a recent op, CNB officers went to a 11th storey unit and knocked on the door and identified themselves. A female occupant was then seen climbing out the window of the unit and scaling down to the 8th storey, near the aircon ledge.An officer immediately rushed to a stairway near the subjects location and calmed her down such that she did not endanger herself any further. She was subsequently rescued unharmed by SCDF officers and warded in hospital for observation as she was 7 months pregnant.With her safety ensured, officers then gained entry into her unit, where they found her 7-year-old son alone, along with drug paraphernalia. Arrangements were made for the welfare of the boy, and he was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.A heart-wrenching scene for all involved - the suspected abuser, the child, and the officers, all except for the trafficker who had been profiting off her addiction.For a DrugFreeSG

An officer immediately rushed to a stairway near the subject's location and calmed her down such that she did not endanger herself any further. She was subsequently rescued unharmed by SCDF officers and warded in hospital for observation as she was 7 months pregnant. With her safety ensured, officers then gained entry into her unit, where they found her 7-year-old son alone, along with drug paraphernalia. Arrangements were made for the welfare of the boy, and he was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin. A heart-wrenching scene for all involved - the suspected abuser, the child, and the officers, all except for the trafficker who had been profiting off her addiction. For a DrugFreeSG.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: ; -- In the evening of 13 July, CNB officers arrested a man in the vicinity of Bedok North Avenue 3. The suspect put up a violent struggle to resist arrest, and attacked officers with a pepper spray. Officers responded with necessary force and subdued him. Officers searched the man, and two of his hideouts situated in the vicinity of Siglap Road as well as Yishun Ave 11. A total of about 141g of heroin, 181g of Ice, 11 Ecstasy tablets and 21 Erimin-5 tablets, with a total estimated street value of $47,000, were seized during the operation. Offensive weapons including a knuckle duster, two Karambit knives and a pepper spray were also recovered. The seizure of 141g of heroin and 181g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 170 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: ; . In the late afternoon of 4 July, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Jalan Bukit Merah. Suspects refused to heed the lawful orders of CNB officers to open the door and forced entry was effected. The 5 men were arrested. About 39g of Ice and 9g of heroin, along with cash amounting to $6,000, were recovered from the 57-year-old man, the registered occupant of the unit. About 31g of heroin was recovered from the 58-year-old man, and a small amount of Ice was also recovered from the 55-year-old man. An estimated 1,023g of Ice, 107g of heroin, 1g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized from various locations in the unit during the search of the unit. A total of about 1,062g of Ice, 147g of heroin and 1g of cannabis, with a total estimated street value of $223,000, were seized during the operation. The seizure of 1,062g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 600 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full Story .drugfreeesg linkinbio

caption: Make Your Pledge for a DrugFreeSG at our Pop-Up Booth this week! This year, we've setup a booth in conjunction with our annual DrugFreeSG Light-Up, which is held on 26 June in solidarity with the UN's International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking. There, you can pledge your support for a drug-free Singapore by placing an anti-drug ribbon into an interactive pledging mechanism, and you'll also get to experience two immersive rooms that mean to highlight the harms of drugs in an experiential manner. Do drop by at Suntec East Atrium (Tower 3) between 10am to 9pm from now till Sunday to show your support!
cleaned_caption: Make Your Pledge for a DrugFreeSG at our Pop-Up Booth this week! This year, we've setup a booth in conjunction with our annual DrugFreeSG Light-Up, which is held on 26 June in solidarity with the UN's International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking. There, you can pledge your support for a drug-free Singapore by placing an anti-drug ribbon into an interactive pledging mechanism, and you'll also get to experience two immersive rooms that mean to highlight the harms of drugs in an experiential manner. Do drop by at Suntec East Atrium (Tower 3) between 10am to 9pm from now till Sunday to show your support!

caption: Distressing scene: Baby found near drugs during op at abusers unitIn a recent op, officers found a drug abuser and her 9-month-old son at her unit. She had been abusing Ice in close proximity of her baby and was the sole caregiver. Living conditions were squalid and drug paraphernalia were found in the open.The baby was brought back to the station and provided with childcare necessities like milk powder by officers. The baby has since been handed over to Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) as the abusers parents are unable to take care of him, while the abuser will be committed to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC).Such scenes, though rare in Singapore, are a stark reminder that those who deal in drugs destroy lives.For a DrugFreeSG
cleaned_caption: Distressing scene: Baby found near drugs during operation at abuser's unit. In a recent operation, officers found a drug abuser and her 9-month-old son at her unit. She had been abusing Ice in close proximity to her baby and was the sole caregiver. Living conditions were squalid and drug paraphernalia were found in the open. The baby was brought back to the station and provided with childcare necessities like milk powder by officers. The baby has since been handed over to the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) as the abuser's parents are unable to take care of him, while the abuser will be committed to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC). Such scenes, though rare in Singapore, are a stark reminder that those who deal in drugs destroy lives. For a DrugFreeSG.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: Drugs worth $55,000, including 173g of cannabis, seized in recent island-wide ops as Singapore Government maintains clear stand on illicit drugs CNB recently concluded a two-week island-wide drug operation which covered areas including Jurong, Marine Parade, Sengkang and Yishun. A total of 146 suspected drug offenders were nabbed.During the operation, controlled drugs of about 28g of heroin, 234g of Ice, 173g of cannabis, a small amount of ketamine and cocaine, 10g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 11 Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, and a bottle of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $55,000. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.The Singapore Governments stand on illicit drugs, including cannabis, is clear - they are harmful, addictive and can destroy lives, families and communities. Examples of other countries have clearly shown that a permissive attitude towards the use of drugs exacts a high cost on society. Therefore, there are strict laws against the trafficking, possession, consumption, and import or export of illicit drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products. CNB would like to remind the public that cannabis is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) in Singapore. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA.Full story:

caption: We are so honored to be mentioned at CNB Drug Free SG s workplan seminar Thank you for the opportunity to spread anti-drug messages especially to the younger audience and parents. We are also extremely grateful to the support from neighbours and the community We hope more people will come onboard to support a Drugs Free Singapore During the CNBs annual workplan seminar on Tuesday (May 31), Minister of State for Home Affairs highlighted the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) plans to strengthen Singapores anti-drug enforcement efforts through the use of technology, continued engagement and community supervision programs. Full speech by Assoc Prof is here In conjunction with the International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking (also known as the World Drug Day) that falls on 26 June every year, we are collaborating with the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) to raise awareness on the harms of drugs and rally the communitys, especially the younger generations support for a drug-free Singapore. Here are some publications you can find at the library:Be Careful, Max! A Story about Stranger Dancer (for preschoolers ages 4 to 6)Captain Drug Buster & Dr. Wacko: The Origin (For children aged 5 to 8)Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The Final Showdown (For children aged 7 to 10) Anti-Drug Ambassador Activity Booklet (for ages 9 to 12) Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The First Encounter (For youths aged 13 to 16) kNOw Cannabis information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors) New Psychoactive Substances information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors)Information toolkit (for parents) Lets all play our part in creating a drug-free Singapore! You can visit or follow CNB on Facebook and Instagram cnb.drugfreesg to find out more about activities planned for the month of June!onehometeam drugsfreesg clementiridgeslibrary clementiridges cnb captaindrugbuster
cleaned_caption: We are so honored to be mentioned at CNB Drug Free SG's workplan seminar. Thank you for the opportunity to spread anti-drug messages, especially to the younger audience and parents. We are also extremely grateful for the support from neighbors and the community. We hope more people will come onboard to support a Drugs Free Singapore. During the CNB's annual workplan seminar on Tuesday (May 31), the Minister of State for Home Affairs highlighted the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) plans to strengthen Singapore's anti-drug enforcement efforts through the use of technology, continued engagement, and community supervision programs. In conjunction with the International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking (also known as World Drug Day) that falls on 26 June every year, we are collaborating with the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) to raise awareness on the harms of drugs and rally the community's, especially the younger generation's, support for a drug-free Singapore. Here are some publications you can find at the library: Be Careful, Max! A Story about Stranger Dancer (for preschoolers ages 4 to 6), Captain Drug Buster & Dr. Wacko: The Origin (For children aged 5 to 8), Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The Final Showdown (For children aged 7 to 10), Anti-Drug Ambassador Activity Booklet (for ages 9 to 12), Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The First Encounter (For youths aged 13 to 16), kNOw Cannabis information booklet (For parents, educators, and counsellors), New Psychoactive Substances information booklet (For parents, educators, and counsellors), Information toolkit (for parents). Let's all play our part in creating a drug-free Singapore! You can visit or follow CNB on Facebook and Instagram to find out more about activities planned for the month of June!

caption: ' : , $. In 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to pose challenges to CNB's ops and strategies. Despite these challenges, CNB dismantled 25 drug syndicates and made significant seizures amounting to an estimated market value of around $18.16 million in 2021.We've also started using portable drug screening test kits, rolled out our Mobile Diary and piloted the Community Supervision programme, while keeping our Preventive Drug Education efforts up. We'll be pushing the implementation of these on the ground while continuing to transform our operations in order to better carry out our mission. Globally, the push for more liberal and "drug-tolerant" policies continues, but we remain committed to our fight for a drug-free Singapore.We look forward to your continued support!OneHomeTeam for a safe, secure and DrugFreeSGFull news release on CNB's Workplan Seminar 2022:

caption: -: - , - In a recent operation, a suspected drug offender climbed out of her third-story window and jumped down onto the second-story parapet. She then attempted to scale down the parapet wall despite warnings from CNB officers below, putting herself at risk of serious injury. An officer quickly moved a nearby trash-bin in place to cushion her descent and she managed to land safely. She was placed under arrest and subsequently brought to the hospital for a check-up. Investigations indicate she is suspected to have consumed heroin not long before officers arrived at her location.

caption: 18 ; CNBOnTheMove OneHomeTeamOn 18 May 2022, ICA officers foiled an attempt to smuggle about 17,704g of heroin, 261g of Ice and 2g of Ecstasy tablets in an arriving Malaysia-registered car via the Woodlands Checkpoint. The driver was arrested. CNB officers mounted follow-up enforcement operations and arrested two other suspected male Malaysian drug offenders in Singapore over 18 and 19 May. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $1,295,000 and is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 8,430 heroin abusers and 150 Ice abusers for a week.Full story: (linkinbio)
cleaned_caption: On 18 May 2022, ICA officers foiled an attempt to smuggle about 17,704g of heroin, 261g of Ice and 2g of Ecstasy tablets in an arriving Malaysia-registered car via the Woodlands Checkpoint. The driver was arrested. CNB officers mounted follow-up enforcement operations and arrested two other suspected male Malaysian drug offenders in Singapore over 18 and 19 May. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $1,295,000 and is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 8,430 heroin abusers and 150 Ice abusers for a week.

caption: #: , $ - CNB recently concluded a 5-day island-wide operation to disrupt drug syndicates and target abusers.In one case, 20kg of cannabis and 6.2kg of heroin were seized. Two Singaporeans and a Malaysian man were arrested. Most of the drugs seized were uncovered at one of the traffickers' hideout in an apartment block in the vicinity of Braddell Hill.The operation also covered other locations including Ang Mo Kio, Bukit Batok and Yio Chu Kang. The total amount of drugs seized during this operation is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 2,960 heroin abusers, 410 'Ice' abusers and 2,910 cannabis abusers for a week.AC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of Central Narcotics Bureau (Operations), said:"Singapore's open economy and connectedness as a regional transport hub, and its proximity to major drug-producing regions, places it in constant danger of being overwhelmed by an influx of narcotics. While the drug situation in Singapore is relatively under control, we cannot take this for granted.This latest haul of drugs has disrupted the syndicates, and CNB will continue to keep up the pressure on them. We are also controlling local demand with our dragnet operations targeting drug abusers."Full story:
cleaned_caption: CNB recently concluded a 5-day island-wide operation to disrupt drug syndicates and target abusers. In one case, 20kg of cannabis and 6.2kg of heroin were seized. The operation also covered other locations including Ang Mo Kio, Bukit Batok, and Yio Chu Kang. The total amount of drugs seized during this operation is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 2,960 heroin abusers, 410 'Ice' abusers, and 2,910 cannabis abusers for a week. The Deputy Director of Central Narcotics Bureau (Operations) said: "Singapore's open economy and connectedness as a regional transport hub, and its proximity to major drug-producing regions, places it in constant danger of being overwhelmed by an influx of narcotics. While the drug situation in Singapore is relatively under control, we cannot take this for granted. This latest haul of drugs has disrupted the syndicates, and CNB will continue to keep up the pressure on them. We are also controlling local demand with our dragnet operations targeting drug abusers." Full story:

caption: #: ; Over 4kg of suspected illicit drugs, including some which were found hidden in tampered milk tea sachets, were seized in a hotel room in the vicinity of Bras Basah Road during a recent CNB operation.In the evening of 9 May, CNB officers raided the hotel room and had to effect forced entry. A 31-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in the bathroom, where he was suspected to have been disposing of illicit drugs into the toilet bowl. Packets of cannabis, as well as other drugs, were recovered from the toilet bowl, cistern and drainage, as well as in other parts of the hotel room.A total of about 65g of Ice, 2,155g of cannabis, 5g of ketamine, 360g of Ecstasy tablets, multiple LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 1,310g of Erimin-5 tablets and 700g of tampered sachets of beverage mix believed to contain controlled drugs were seized during the operation. The seizure of 2,155g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 307 abusers.Superintendent Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said:It is not surprising that drug trafficking syndicates have continued to exploit various novel drug concealment methods to evade CNBs persistent enforcement actions. In this operation, we saw how syndicates have tampered milk tea sachets to hide their drugs. CNB will spare no efforts in launching well-timed operations to prevent these drugs from contaminating our society. We will also carry out our duty to prevent unscrupulous offenders from enticing the unsuspecting public and youths to consume these drugs.Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing.Full story:
cleaned_caption: Over 4kg of suspected illicit drugs, including some which were found hidden in tampered milk tea sachets, were seized in a hotel room in the vicinity of Bras Basah Road during a recent CNB operation. In the evening of 9 May, CNB officers raided the hotel room and had to effect forced entry. A 31-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in the bathroom, where he was suspected to have been disposing of illicit drugs into the toilet bowl. Packets of cannabis, as well as other drugs, were recovered from the toilet bowl, cistern and drainage, as well as in other parts of the hotel room. A total of about 65g of Ice, 2,155g of cannabis, 5g of ketamine, 360g of Ecstasy tablets, multiple LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 1,310g of Erimin-5 tablets and 700g of tampered sachets of beverage mix believed to contain controlled drugs were seized during the operation. The seizure of 2,155g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 307 abusers. Superintendent, Director of Intelligence Division, said: It is not surprising that drug trafficking syndicates have continued to exploit various novel drug concealment methods to evade CNB's persistent enforcement actions. In this operation, we saw how syndicates have tampered milk tea sachets to hide their drugs. CNB will spare no efforts in launching well-timed operations to prevent these drugs from contaminating our society. We will also carry out our duty to prevent unscrupulous offenders from enticing the unsuspecting public and youths to consume these drugs. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing.

In the evening of 9 May, CNB officers raided the hotel room and had to effect forced entry. A 31-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in the bathroom, where he was suspected to have been disposing of illicit drugs into the toilet bowl. Packets of cannabis, as well as other drugs, were recovered from the toilet bowl, cistern and drainage, as well as in other parts of the hotel room. A total of about 65g of Ice, 2,155g of cannabis, 5g of ketamine, 360g of Ecstasy tablets, multiple LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 1,310g of Erimin-5 tablets and 700g of tampered sachets of beverage mix believed to contain controlled drugs were seized during the operation. The seizure of 2,155g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 307 abusers. Superintendent, Director of Intelligence Division, said: "It is not surprising that drug trafficking syndicates have continued to exploit various novel drug concealment methods to evade CNB's persistent enforcement actions. In this operation, we saw how syndicates have tampered milk tea sachets to hide their drugs. CNB will spare no efforts in launching well-timed operations to prevent these drugs from contaminating our society. We will also carry out our duty to prevent unscrupulous offenders from enticing the unsuspecting public and youths to consume these drugs." Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing. Full story:

caption: #: . , On 26 April 2022, three Singaporean men aged between 20 and 22 were arrested for suspected drug activities by CNB officers. One of the men was escorted to a locked riser in the vicinity of Eunos Crescent, where, using a key found on him, officers unlocked the riser and recovered about 2,312g of heroin.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.Full story:

caption: #: , 60, . 735 254 In the afternoon of 22 April, CNB officers arrested a 61-year-old man in the vicinity of Serangoon Road. About 245g of Ice was recovered from him, along with cash amounting to close to $3,400. In a follow-up operation, two other men (aged 65 and 67), and a 65-year-old woman were arrested in the same vicinity. A total of about 521g of heroin, 3g of Ice and cash amounting to more than $1,500 were recovered from the 67-year-old man. The 65-year-old man and woman were escorted to their hideout in a private residential estate in the same vicinity, where about 214g of heroin, 6g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from the residential unit. Cash amounting to more than $12,000 were also recovered from the 65-year-old man. The seizure of 735g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 350 abusers for a week, and the seizure of 254g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 150 abusers. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act, if a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine) or 250g of methamphetamine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story: (linkinbio)

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 32 - In an island-wide operation from 18 and 19 April 2022, CNB officers arrested 32 suspected drug offenders, The operation was targeted at drug transactions conducted through chat applications. Areas covered during this operation include Bukit Panjang, Compassvale, Jurong West and Sembawang.A total of about 191g of Ice, 718g of cannabis, 4g of ketamine, 4g of cocaine, 714g of Ecstasy tablets, multiple LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 201 Erimin-5 tablets and two bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth about $140,000.In one of the cases, CNB officers arrested a 26-year-old man in the vicinity of Bukit Batok West on 18 April evening. The man was escorted to his residence in the same vicinity, where a total of about 173g of crystalline substances believed to contain Ice, 488g of cannabis, 713g of Ecstasy tablets and other drugs were seized. A 24-year-old man who later visited the same residential unit was also arrested for suspected drug offences. SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of CNBs Intelligence Division, said: CNB had carried out a similar operation in November last year, targeted at drug transactions conducted on encrypted chat applications where 50 suspected drug offenders were arrested. Drug offenders naively assume that these chat applications can afford them the anonymity to facilitate their illegal activities, so that they can evade CNBs detection but they are wrong.This latest operation shows that CNB is not letting up on our efforts against drug offenders, regardless of whichever methods they use to mask their activities.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full Story: (linkinbio)

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 84 - ; 231 , 304 ' In an island-wide operation from 10 to 14 April 2022, CNB officers arrested 84 suspected drug offenders across Singapore in areas including Hougang, Telok Blangah, and Yishun. A total of 231g of heroin, 304g of Ice, 36g of ketamine, 113 Ecstasy tablets, eight Erimin-5 tablets and 16 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of more than $70,000. The youngest arrested is a 16-year-old male Singaporean for suspected drug abuse.In one of the cases, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 10 and arrested a 55-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking offences. Forced entry was effected as the man had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers. A total of about 174g of heroin and 6g of Ice, along with various drug paraphernalia, were seized from the unit. On the same day, CNB conducted a follow-up operation to arrest the 55-year-olds drug clients. Two Singaporean men, aged 44 and 45, were subsequently arrested in the same vicinity.SUPT Mohd Hamzah Yusop, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 1, said of the island-wide operation: This island-wide operation is part of CNBs sustained commitment to keep our streets safe from the scourge of drugs. Our officers have been diligent in following up on all drug leads, and we will spare no effort to track down both drug traffickers and drug abusers.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full Story: (linkinbio)

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 84 - ; 231 , 304 ' In an island-wide operation from 10 to 14 April 2022, CNB officers arrested 84 suspected drug offenders across Singapore in areas including Hougang, Telok Blangah, and Yishun. A total of 231g of heroin, 304g of Ice, 36g of ketamine, 113 Ecstasy tablets, eight Erimin-5 tablets and 16 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of more than $70,000. The youngest arrested is a 16-year-old male Singaporean for suspected drug abuse.In one of the cases, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 10 and arrested a 55-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking offences. Forced entry was effected as the man had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers. A total of about 174g of heroin and 6g of Ice, along with various drug paraphernalia, were seized from the unit. On the same day, CNB conducted a follow-up operation to arrest the 55-year-olds drug clients. Two Singaporean men, aged 44 and 45, were subsequently arrested in the same vicinity.SUPT Mohd Hamzah Yusop, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 1, said of the island-wide operation: This island-wide operation is part of CNBs sustained commitment to keep our streets safe from the scourge of drugs. Our officers have been diligent in following up on all drug leads, and we will spare no effort to track down both drug traffickers and drug abusers.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full Story: (linkinbio)

caption: CNBOntheMove: 9 , 0.5 ; In the afternoon of 30 March, CNB officers arrested a Malaysian man in the vicinity of Beach Road, and about 4,876g of cannabis was recovered from him. The man was escorted to his residence where an addition of about 3,877g of cannabis and 463g of heroin were also seized.The total quantity of 8,753g of cannabis seized can feed the addiction of about 1,250 abusers for a week, while the 463g of heroin seized can feed the addiction of about 220 abusers for a week.Superintendent Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said: The drug seizures in this operation serve as a reminder of our firm zero-tolerance approach towards drugs, including cannabis. Cannabis is an illicit drug in Singapore. It is addictive, and its use can produce several harmful effects, such as irreversible brain damage, brain volume reduction, and serious mental / psychiatric illnesses.Beyond their physical effects, illicit drugs exact a heavy price on our families and communities. Livelihoods are lost, relationships are destroyed, and families are broken.In order to protect our society from the harm of drugs, CNB will continue to enforce strict laws against the trafficking, possession, consumption and import or export of illicit drugs. CNB will also not let up on our enforcement efforts to arrest drug abusers who purchase drugs from syndicates.Investigations are ongoing.Full Story: (linkinbio)

caption: CNBOntheMove: - ; , In an island-wide operation from 14 to 23 March, CNB arrested 100 suspected drug offenders across Singapore in areas including Choa Chu Kang, Macpherson, Seng Kang and Tampines. A total of about 279g of heroin, 404g of Ice, 6,308g of cannabis, 237g of ketamine, 2g of new psychoactive substances, more than 709g of Ecstasy tablets, 197 Erimin-5 tablets, 19 LSD stamps and 200ml of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $382,000. The youngest arrested is a 16-year-old male Singaporean for suspected drug abuse.At one particular location in the vicinity of Jalan Damai, a 22-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug-related offences. About 3kg of cannabis was seized, along with other drugs, as well as several knives, a chopper and an airsoft gun which were found in his room. He was then brought to his official place of residence nearby where various drug paraphernalia and another airsoft gun were seized.AC Lim Fung Suan, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 2, said of the island-wide operation: CNB has worked tirelessly to stem the flow of drugs to keep Singapore safe. Our officers have put in a lot of hard work to bring drug offenders to justice, even amidst dangerous and unpredictable situations involving offenders who may turn violent against them. At CNB and the Home Team, we believe that drugs have no place in Singapore, and we are committed to keep our streets safe from drugs.Investigations are ongoing. Full Story: go.gov.sg/100suspectsarrested25mar2022 ( )

caption: : - . .In a follow-up operation on 16 March 2022, 11 suspected male drug abusers (comprising four Singaporeans and seven foreigners) were arrested. A total of about 280g of cocaine, 54g of cannabis and cannabis seeds, 33 Ecstasy tablets and 245g of brown powder suspected to contain controlled drugs were seized in the operations. Superintendent Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said:Drug abuse is a persistent threat that targets every vulnerable segment of our society. It exacts a heavy price on abusers, their families and our community. This is why Singapore takes a zero-tolerance approach towards drugs to prevent harm to our people and society, and to create an environment where our children can live and play safely. Those who visit or live in Singapore must abide by our laws. If they choose to break them, they must be prepared to face the consequences. CNB will not hesitate to take action against these drug offenders and will keep up our enforcement efforts. Our message is clear - there is no place for drugs in our society.Investigations into the drug activities of all 14 arrested suspects are ongoing. CNBonthemove Full Story: go.gov.sg/300gcocainebooksmar22cnb ( )

Investigations into the drug activities of all 14 arrested suspects are ongoing. CNBonthemove Full Story: go.gov.sg/300gcocainebooksmar22cnb ( )

caption: #: - ; , During the operations that took place on 4 and 5 March, 3 men (aged between 50 and 55), and a 29 year old woman were arrested. CNB seized a total of about 1,494g of heroin, 428g of Ice, 78g of cannabis, 326g of Ecstasy tablets, 303 Erimin-5 tablets and 3g of Yaba tablets. These drugs had a total estimated street value of $221,000.The 55 year old and 50 year old were caught when CNB officers intercepted the vehicles they were respectively driving near Chai Chee Street and North Canal Road on 4 March. In a followup ops the same evening, CNB officers raided a unit in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 3 and arrested a 54 year old man. A 29 year old woman was arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Eunos in the early hours of 5 March.Drug paraphernalia and weighing scales were also seized during the ops. Superintendent William Tan, Senior Assistant Director of CNBs Intelligence Division, said of the operation: The drugs seized from this operation can feed the addiction of about 1,000 abusers for a week. But the harm goes beyond this number. Illicit drugs are harmful and addictive, and the despicable actions of drug traffickers can destroy lives, families and communities... CNB will continue with our targeted operations against drug syndicates to prevent drugs from flowing into the streets. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine) or 250g of methamphetamine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.Read more here:
